title.narrative: Support to Human Rights in SL

description.narrative: The project goes into its second phase in supporting the capacity strengthening of the HRC for Human Rights Protection and Promotion in Sierra Leone.

activity-description.narrative: To strengthen the capacity of Human right commission on issues of fundamental human rights in Sierra Leone

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1.1: # of HRCSL staff (m/f) trained functional areas, resource mobilisation (RM), and human rights # of DHRC members trained on gender justice frameworks. # of Parliamentarian trained on human rights-based approach to legislative review. 1.2: # updated policies to strengthen gender aware service delivery. 1.3: An updated gender sensitive HRCSL Act in place (Yes/No) 1.4: # of gendered study on the impact of private businesses on human rights carried out.
2.1: # of gender justice and human rights radio discussion programmes aired. 2.2: # of functioning gender sensitive human rights and peace clubs (HRPC) in secondary schools.
INDICATOR 2022
Output 1
i. 1.1: Human rights and related complaints addressed through mobile complaint hearing process and functioning Referral Partnership forums (RPF). ii. 1.2: Public inquiry into the conduct of law enforcement officers in the maintenance of law and order instituted by HRCSL iii. 1.3: An updated gender sensitive HRCSL Act in place.
Output 2 - 2.1: # of gender aware national policy on Business & Human Right (BHR) developed and validated.

comment.narrative:
1.1: 28 HRCSL staff trained on human rights, 42 members of DHRCs on human rights, No Parliamentarian trained. 1.2: Outdated HRCSL policies and no national policy on Business and Human Rights (B+HR) (2020). 1.3: HRCSL Act 2004 reviewed awaiting passage into law 1.4: 1 Study carried out by HRC in 2017 but limited in scope.
2.1: 9 radio discussion programmes aired (2020) 2.2: 10 HRPC established.
BASELINE 2022
Output 1
i. 1.1: Human rights and related complaints addressed through mobile complaint hearing process and functioning Referral Partnership forums (RPF). ii. 1.2: Public inquiry into the conduct of law enforcement officers in the maintenance of law and order instituted by HRCSL iii. 1.3: An updated gender sensitive HRCSL Act in place.
Output 2
- 2.1: No national policy on Business & Human Right (BHR)

1.1: HRCSL staff (20 (10 each year in functional areas, 32 DHRCs, 50 Parliamentarian. 1.2:Updated HRCSL Finance, Communication policies, Resource mobilisation, Human Resource Manual, a national policy on (B+HR) developed. 1.3: HRCSL Act, 2004 amended and Updated. 1.4: 1 Comprehensive baseline study on business and human rights conducted
2.1: 25 (12 (2021), 13 (2022). 2.2: 10 (5 each year).

3.1.1 10 (M9, F1), staff of HRCSL, including 3 Commissioners benefitted from short courses on leadership, procurement, project management and Monitoring and Evaluation by the Institute of Public Administration and Management 3.1.2 Five (5) including four reviewed and one newly developed fixed Asset Policy indicates target was exceeded by 1 (25%). Outdated policies including the Finance Policy, Communication Policy and Strategy, Resource Mobilisation Strategy and Human Resource Manual, were reviewed and updated, and a Fixed Asset Policy developed. 3.1.3 Drafting instructions on the revised HRCSL Act developed and submitted to the Attorney General and Minster of Justice for submission to Cabinet and subsequent enactment 3.1.4 One (1) baseline study on how private/informal businesses across the country affect the enjoyment of human rights. Staff and managers of Informal businesses in the east, west north and south were consulted 3.1.5 Four (4) regional stakeholders consultations conducted to gauge stakeholders perspectives on the 274 Third Cycle UPR recommendations. 3.2.1 A total of four (4) radio programmes were held in Freetown and listeners educated on COVID-19 and human rights, SGBV, children and women’s rights, gender empowerment policy, Sexual Offences (Amended) Act 2019, Women’s Rights in the Administration of Justice (approximately 800,000 people were targeted- 500 males and 300 females). 3.2.2 4 (annual target achieved) human rights outreach campaigns to schools in Freetown, Port Loko, Kabala and Kono. Total beneficiaries was 160 (M84, F76 (136 pupils and 24 teachers)) from 14 secondary schools. 18 Human Rights and Peace Clubs (HRPC) were established, 15 in the regions and 3 in Freetown. 3.2.3. 4 (80% of annual target archieved) mobile complaints hearing were held and bebefitted a total of 224 participants (males 178 and females 46). A total of 28 complaints were received (22 males and 6 females). The outcome of the complaints include: one (1) was resolved, seven (7) referred and the Commission proffered advise in four (4), nine (9) are pending for further action after assessment and the Commission will monitor/follow-up on the other seven (7) matters which are already in court.

i. One HRCSL gender responsive Institutional capacity assessment conducted and capacity building plan developed. ii. HRCSL Act, 2004 amended and updated. iii. 25 HRCSL personnel, 70 MDAs & CSOs and 24 DHRC TOT trained (disaggregated by gender) iv. A 2-day national consultative conference on UPR involving 80 persons (disaggregated by gender and category of participants) organised. v. At least 3 regional trainings (each for 2 days) on the revised COVID-19 SOP targeting 90 security and human rights personnel conducted. vi. At least 25 (5 per region) complaints received, investigated/referred and handled conclusively

 One (1) Comprehensive HRC capacity assessment done, and report produced.  One (1) Capacity Building Plan developed.  One (1) study-tour conducted to Uganda Human Rights Commission (UHRC) benefitted 7 staff who had the opportunity to learn best practices of the Uganda  Fourth Generation HRC Strategic Plan (2021-2025) developed.  HRCSL Act 2004 reviewed and yet to be enacted in Parliament.  28 (M21, F7) HRCSL personnel trained (5 new Commissioners and 23 staff).  42 (M33, F9) members of the DHRCs on gender concepts, human rights, the treaty body reporting process, complaints handling and investigation and ADR mechanisms.  70 (M50, F20) CSO and MDA representatives benefitted from training on the UPR process and reporting on the SDGs and African Agenda 2063.  90 (M65, F25) law enforcement officers benefitted from 2 regional trainings on rights-based approach and NaCOVERC’s SOPs in responding to COVI-19.  conducted 10 outreach to schools and 10 HRPC established. 50 beneficiaries (36 pupils and 14 teachers (M27, F23) benefitted from the training conducted in the Western Urban.  Supported 3 regional consultations on the UPR, leading the preparation of the Commission’s shadow report and two shadow reports by CSOs.

Output 1
- A total of 100 human rights and related complaints received and processed to provide remedy for complainants. - 200 officers (Police, military, metropolitan police, correctional officers and road safety corps) investigated and appropriate action instituted. - HRCSL Act, 2004 amended and updated.
Output 2
- 2.1: A new national policy on BHR in place to regulate private businesses.
Output 3
- 4 (National Reporting Mechanism (NRM) Act enacted, discussion on passage of Human Rights defenders Bill initiated, the Criminal Procedure Act (CPA) Bill and Gender Empowerment Bill) Bills passed into law.
